results.title: These three
results.creator_credit: William Wyler, Samuel Goldwyn and Samuel Goldwyn Company
results.brief_description: This cinematic masterpiece, directed with enormous sensitivity by William Wyler, tells the story of two women (Merle Oberon and Miriam Hopkins) who fall in love with the same man (Joel McCrea) and the damage to their lives that can be caused to all three by the malicious lies of a spiteful teenage schoolgirl (Bonita Granville). This powerful story of gossip and suspicion was based on Lillian Hellman’s controversial Broadway success “The Children’s Hour.” The appearance of Walter Brennan as the local taxi driver brings the only light relief to such a dramatic film and the outstanding performance of Bonita Granville was nominated for an Academy Award.
results.creator_credit_for_label: William Wyler, Samuel Goldwyn and Samuel Goldwyn Company

results.title: The Truman show
results.creator_credit: Peter Weir, Adam Schroeder, Edward S. Feldman, Andrew Niccol, Scott Rudin and Paramount Pictures
results.brief_description: Truman Burbank (Jim Carrey) is the star of a television experiment: he does not know that since birth his life has been the centre of a television show called The Truman Show.

constellations_other.name: Fake news: too little too late
constellations_other.description: Unbound Creations’ Headliner: NoviNews explores the impact of the media and fake news on society, something that is fast becoming one of the biggest concerns of our age.

results.creator_credit_for_label: Peter Weir, Adam Schroeder, Edward S. Feldman, Andrew Niccol, Scott Rudin and Paramount Pictures
results.description: Truman Burbank (Jim Carrey) is the star of a television experiment: he does not know that since birth his life has been the centre of a television show called The Truman Show. The world he lives in is one giant TV set and his family, his marriage and his work are all shams. Gradually, however, Truman comes to suspect that there is something not quite right with his life. As Truman attempts to discover the truth behind the banality of his existence, his attempts are frustrated by the control and power of the man (Ed Harris) who has created “his” life; and by the expectations of a TV audience who have themselves grown up on The Truman Show. From this fantastical premise, Peter Weir has created a moving fable about our obsession with media and the destructive potential of such obsession. Truman exists in a world where reality is meaningless but the film posits that the audiences who watch his life unfold on television are themselves blind to the distinction between media and the real. Weir has crafted a morality tale which utilises the best of contemporary studio craft to present a tale with the simple force and grace of a modern fairy tale.
description_for_label: Truman Burbank (Jim Carrey) is the star of a television experiment: he does not know that since birth his life has been the centre of a television show called The Truman Show. From this fantastical premise, Peter Weir has created a moving fable about our obsession with media and the destructive potential of such obsession. Truman exists in a world where reality is meaningless but the film posits that the audiences who watch his life unfold on television are themselves blind to the distinction between media and the real. results.title: Zoo Family. - Volume 2.
results.creator_credit: Chris Sheil, Howard Neil and Crawford Productions
results.brief_description: Zoo Family was filmed on location at the Melbourne Zoological Gardens and each adventure revolves around the zoo vet and his children, Susie and Nick who manage to get into all sorts of adventures. However it is the animals who are the real stars of the film.

results.title: The Trouble with medicine. [Part 2]
results.creator_credit: Stefan Moore, Martin Freeth, WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.) and BBC
results.brief_description: Last three episodes of a major and controversial international series which looks at the challenges that face medical science today. “Disordered states” (Dir: Peter Montagnon): Explores mental illness and how the treatment of patients differs in different countries. India, Italy and the United States are shown as examples. “Pandemic” (Dir: Susan Lambert, Stefan Moore): Looks at AIDS programs in the USA where the high-tech approach to medicine is out of reach of most of those who need it, in Thailand, where the entire population is at threat, and in Australia where there has been some success in containing the disease. “Life support” (Dir: Henry Singer) The final episode looks at how modern medicine deals with the frail, elderly and the dying, exploring issues such as when is enough life support enough? Warning - some scenes in this video may disturb some viewers.

results.title: The True story of Eskimo Nell
results.creator_credit: Richard Franklin, Ron Baneth and Quest Films
results.brief_description: Two horny rogues on a road trip are out to find the illustrious lover (aka ‘womper’) from Alaska named Eskimo Nell. Dead Eye Dick (Max Gillies) and Mexico Pete (Serge Lazareff) travel around the Australian goldfields trying to bed women wherever they go. Dead Eye Dick is more talk than action as he has his heart set on finding Nell. Very much the storyteller, Dead Eye’s fanciful tales land the two in trouble and they often have to leave town in a hurry. Boobs and bawdiness abound in this ‘historical’ comedy drama from writers Alan Hopgood and Richard Franklin - also produced and directed by Franklin. Music by Brian May. Cast includes Abigail, Grahame Bond, Kris McQuade, Elli Maclure, Paul Vachon, Anthony Bazell, Ernie Bourne.

results.title: The Trouble with medicine. [Part 1]
results.creator_credit: Stefan Moore, Martin Freeth, WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.) and BBC
results.brief_description: The first three episodes of a major and controversial international series which looks at the challenges that face medical science today. “Conceiving the future” (Dir: Tim Clark): Looks at genetics and the ethical dilemmas that arise from new technologies and being further able to pinpoint defects and abnormalities in unborn children. Asking questions such as what is abnormal? “Code of silence” (Dir: Stephen White): Examines to the heart of the doctor/patient relationship to find some extreme differences in the way physicians talk to their clients. “Temple of science” (Dir: Stefan Moore): Looks at the trend towards hi-tech medicine and specialisation, and Australia’s lead being the U.S.A. Warning: some scenes may be disturbing to some viewers.

Warning: some scenes may be disturbing to some viewers.

results.title: The Trouble with Harry [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Alfred Hitchcock, Alfred J Hitchcock Productions and Universal Pictures
results.brief_description: The trouble with Harry is that he’s dead, and while nobody else seems to mind, everybody thinks they are responsible for his death. After many burials and unearthings of the corpse, and a few blossoming romances between the major characters, the real cause of Harry’s death is revealed, and Harry troubles nobody again. “The Trouble with Harry” is a quirky comedy-mystery set in then autumnal splendour of New England. It is a decidedly different film from Hitchcock, in which Shirley Maclaine makes her screen debut. Includes music score by Bernard Herrmann. Cast includes Edmund Gwen, John Forsythe, Mildred Natwick and Jerry Mathers. Screenplay by John Michael Hayes, based on the novel by Jack Trevor Story. Cinematography by Robert Burks. Edited by Alma Macrorie. Music by Bernard Herrmann.

results.title: Warlords II for Mac
results.material_description: Floppy disk videogame. Four 3 1/2 inch floppy disks, registration card, subscription card, catalogue and manual in cardboard box
results.brief_description: Warlords II refines on the formula that made the previous game so successful. New to the game is the addition of “fog of war”, where enemy units may be concealed from the map if a player’s own units are not close enough to see them. The interface and graphics have been upgraded and a suite of tools have been added to facilitate its multiplayer experience. This include a play by e-mail feature, a random map generator and a map editor.

results.title: The Trouble with Harry
results.creator_credit: Alfred Hitchcock, Alfred J Hitchcock Productions and Universal Pictures
results.brief_description: The trouble with Harry is that he’s dead, and while nobody else seems to mind, everybody thinks they are responsible for his death. After many burials and unearthings of the corpse, and a few blossoming romances between the major characters, the real cause of Harry’s death is revealed, and Harry troubles nobody again. “The Trouble with Harry” is a quirky comedy-mystery set in the autumnal splendour of New England. It is a decidedly different film from Hitchcock, in which Shirley Maclaine makes her screen debut. Includes music score by Bernard Herrmann. Cast includes Edmund Gwen, John Forsythe, Shirley Maclaine, Mildred Natwick and Jerry Mathers. Based on the novel by Jack Trevor.

results.title: Aussie Rules Footy for NES
results.material_description: Cartridge videogame. Cartridge, cartridge sleeve and manual in cardboard box
results.brief_description:
Aussie Rules Footy was Beam Software’s first Nintendo Entertainment System (NES) sports game developed exclusively for the Australian market. Despite simple controls, its clever design captured the high-energy, competitive spirit of the sport, featuring spectacular high marking and pushing other players out from under a mark.

It also contained Beam’s signature sense of humour. Though voice samples were unusual in NES games of the era, Aussie Rules Footy used voice lines like the deadpan umpire’s “out of bounds on the full”, which complemented the droll text-based commentary between quarters.

Despite the official AFL logo on the box, it’s unlikely the game was licensed, which could be why the 18 playable teams don’t match their real-life counterparts, with curious inclusions like Darwin, Canberra and Hobart.
results.description:

It also contained Beam’s signature sense of humour. Though voice samples were unusual in NES games of the era, Aussie Rules Footy used voice lines like the deadpan umpire’s “out of bounds on the full”, which complemented the droll text-based commentary between quarters.

Despite the official AFL logo on the box, it’s unlikely the game was licensed, which could be why the 18 playable teams don’t match their real-life counterparts, with curious inclusions like Darwin, Canberra and Hobart.

Aussie Rules Footy was Beam Software’s first Nintendo Entertainment System (NES) sports game developed exclusively for the Australian market. Despite simple controls, its clever design captured the high-energy, competitive spirit of the sport, featuring spectacular high marking and pushing other players out from under a mark.

It also contained Beam’s signature sense of humour. Though voice samples were unusual in NES games of the era, Aussie Rules Footy used voice lines like the deadpan umpire’s “out of bounds on the full”, which complemented the droll text-based commentary between quarters.
